*[Bug 18892] Support the use of netrc when using the libcurl downloader?*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18892>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
In principle it should be possible, certainly it shouldn't be hard to
implement: <https://curl.se/libcurl/c/CURLOPT_NETRC.html>

I don't know your use case, but my general worry these days would be saving
passwords in cleartext in a file. Isn't there  a better (safer) solution in
your case? From my reading, it seems curl only supports netrc files with
passwords in cleartext. E.g. git supports at least gpg-encrypted netrc files,
but this feature hasn't been added to curl
(<https://curl.se/mail/archive-2019-04/0016.html>). 

The libcurl build in Rtools is with SSPI enabled. If you were looking only at
Windows, couldn't you get a safer solution that way via the OS?

text:
*[Bug 18892] Support the use of netrc when using the libcurl downloader?*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18892>

--- Comment #2 from Kevin Ushey (<mailto:kevinushey@gmail.com|kevinushey@gmail.com>) ---
Ultimately, the goal is to get credentials visible to R's `download.file()`,
preferably with certain credentials mapped to certain URLs / hosts. (E.g.
because authentication is required to access a user's internal R package
repository.) Ideally, this mechanism should be available for all of Windows /
macOS / Linux. Using `.netrc` seemed like a natural mechanism to make this
possible.

In theory, one could build their own tooling on top of `download.file()` and
ensure the `headers` argument is set appropriately. However, this doesn't help
if `download.file()` is invoked from a separate R function; e.g.
`download.packages()` / `available.packages()` / `install.packages()`. Ideally,
all of the existing R tooling for downloading / installing packages would be
able to work without the need for a separate facade on top.

The curl documentation does say (<https://curl.se/docs/manpage.html#-n>):

> curl does not complain if that file does not have the right permissions (it should be neither world- nor group-readable).

but I imagine users / administrators who have such `.netrc` files are ensuring
they have the appropriate permissions (typically, 0600). R could also check and
validate that requirement itself if that were a worry.

Relatedly, some organizations are (quite unfortunately) encouraging users to
encode credentials directly in the URL to their package repository. This
exposes the credentials in an unfortunate way -- R uses the provided URL when
storing the local cache from `available.packages()`; if the URL to a package
repository contained credentials, those credentials would then be leaked as
names on the filesystem within the R temporary directory.

```
                dest <- file.path(if (cache_user_dir)
                  tools::R_user_dir("base", "cache")
                else tempdir(), paste0("repos_", URLencode(repos,
                  TRUE), ".rds"))
```

The use of a `.netrc` file would be an easy to adopt improvement over this
scenario, although that issue might warrant its own separate fix.

For what it's worth, most users are still storing SSH keys within `~/.ssh` as
plaintext files as well. All this to say -- the use of `.netrc` might not be
the best solution, but I believe it's overall a step in the right direction.

used elsewhere regarding macOS.

$

```

```
